pros: They work with your time, they have good benefits, they treat people with respect, they have your interest at heart
cons: Nothing but very good place to work

review_title: It is not what it seems
pros: Workload and expectations can be simple Culture can be very welcoming and friendly to patients Coworkers can be very friendly Lots of chances to get overtime Some outstanding, knowledgable staff
cons: Lots of fearful staff Lots of staff that avoid responsibility Lots of staff that bend rules to benefit themselves AND patients Staff-patient relationships can be very volatile and chaotic Bad energy spreads too easily from patient to patient, staff to staff, patient to staff and vice versa There is a lack of deescalation skills Not enough resources for staff, even less for patients Lack of specialized care unless its for patients who are very problematic and dangerous. The others that need that type of care usually have struggle and wait.

pros:
Helps the poor and the mentally ill - good mission but maybe inconsistent with profit motive
Some genuinely helpful doctors and counselors, nice co-workers and we have fun supporting each other although it is often stressful
Salary is okay
cons:
The CEO is a micromanager. That will be fine  in other situations but she is not competent. She has a manner that is brash and aggressive. She was sent to PIW from Boston - we googled and found out that her hospital there was closed by the government.  It makes sense. They should replace her because she will run this place to the ground. But then again, UHS probably likes her because of profits.

Old building

No security guards - we were the security 

Many are not competent at their jobs - they need training that they are not getting

job_title: Clinical Assessment Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: PIW is a small place which mean there is great camaraderie between the employees and management staff.
cons:
The leaders of this organization do not understand the current reality of mapping out the course for improving employee engagement and, along with it, patient satisfaction. Most issues impacting employee engagement and patient care include:

•  Lack of recognition by managers who have the attitude that, "It's their job. I don't need to give employees kudos for just doing their job."

•  An overt, or covert, acceptance of behaviors not in the best interest of patients. "She's a great nurse but can be a little terse at times."

•  The feeling that "good is good enough."

•  Blaming or finger-pointing between departments (silos): "If the nurses would just do their jobs, our scores would be better."

•  Complacency or acceptance of the status quo and excusing away the patient satisfaction scores. "Our patients expect too much, period. And this community is different."

review_title: Is not the place to work if you value your license and your patients
job_title: STaff Registered Nurse in Washington, DC
pros: Pays 2-3 dollars more than other local hospitals
cons: NO SECURITY anywhere, female staff has to physically restraint male patients, No parking or subsidy, Costly health Insurance, Sloppy unprofessional culture, NO COMPUTERS everything is handwritten, Paper charts

job_title: Psychiatric Counselor in Montgomery Village, MD
pros: The people who you work with are the best. It is like having a second family at times. The practical clinical experience is great.
cons: The administration does not truly support the employees on the units. There is also the mandated joining of the union that does little to benefit the employees.

pros: Pretty good clinical experience and centrally located.
cons: Consistently understaffed, too high patient loads, low pay, unsafe working conditions, no appreciation from upper management and administration only castigation and blame for things out of ones control. Sadly, only about money keeping beds filled) and not patient care.
Staff competency, safety, support from the corporate office
